text: I'm Matt gross
the frugal traveler for the New York
Times this summer I'm embarking on the
grand tour of Europe over 12 weeks I'll
seek out ancient history and
contemporary culture
I'll find cool hotels and eat memorable
meals and I'll stretch the US dollar to
the breaking point in the summer Gdansk
Poland historic seaport on its baltic
coast is a blur of activity among the
stately houses dating back 400 years
tourists mill and massive numbers
buskers play old songs and newer ones
and every once in a while something sort
of weird happens this was a performance
by Lesage who a theater troupe from
Canada who in the middle of Gdansk
medieval gothic old town discovered a
strange undersea world
Lesage food comes to get ants as part of
feta the International open-air and
Street Theater Festival it launched in
1997 the yoga dance turned 1,000 years
old and has been going strong ever since
this year the theater groups addressed
the big issues facing humanity
everything from insomnia to climate
change at least I think the Danish group
Fluxus was addressing climate change six
wedding guests survived a flood that
wipes out the entire world and are stuck
on a rooftop with nothing but champagne
cakes and each other will the human race
survive likewise the group performing
seven mere projects the emigrants mixed
fun with a message talking about
unfortunately I was staying at the Villa
Yolanda a nice apartment house that was
nowhere near this beautiful environment
so every morning I had to walk through
the wilderness to catch the tram
to get a better view of this beautiful
environment I hiked up Grados come out
and met young Danny look a history
student and guy there was st. Mary's
Cathedral the largest brick church in
Europe and the town hall with its
elaborate system of bells lovely they
may be but as Yun pointed out they're
not necessarily old unfortunately the
the horror of the humble things from the
Second World War
desk was destroyed and more than 90%
almost all this building we
reconstructed after the Second World War
reconstruction is still going on
especially now that Poland a member of
the European Union has an economy that's
booming up here on the hill Gdansk add
just opened its 17th century
fortifications to the public it was the
most important city it was our hands at
the biggest and the strongest cities in
the east north is to rob Gdansk
importance on the trade routes also made
it an important Centre for shipbuilding
a tradition it carried on throughout the
20th century in the 21st however that
tradition may not survive the Gdansk
shipyards are facing bankruptcy and
possible closure a sad fate for an
industry that spawned the Solidarity
movement and eventually brought down
Polish communism
for a quick history lesson I checked out
the roads to freedom exhibition the
exhibit tries to show what life was
actually like under communism stores had
few products even toilet paper was
scarce and political activists wound up
in jail but in 1980 an electrician named
lek valensa led a strike of workers of
advanced shipyards that finally forced
the government's hand and there would be
nine more years before Paul and held
free election lenses solidarity movement
had knocked serious cracks in the
communist system today with all the
tourists around it's hard to see the
communist past in fact sometimes there
are so many tourists you want to find
your own a peaceful corner and hide and
so with directions from yon that's just
what I did
accompanied by my friends Monica and
goes yeah maybe but the alley behind st.
John's Church was also beautiful and
quiet and just about abandoned an
excellent setting for some Street
